div.p: While it may sound simplistic...some of the most important reading you do
for a course will be reading the syllabus.
That will serve as your guide...your road map...throughout the course.
It may come as a surprise but many students don't read the syllabus and later find
out they missed a deadline or submitted something incorrectly.
So, pay attention to and refer often to this very important document.
First things first...read the textbook as assigned.
Resist the temptation to rely on classroom discussions, PowerPoint presentations,
and lecture notes as a means to understanding the material.
Instructors use these methodologies to create a better understanding
of the material presented in the text.
So you've just taken that 386 page sociology textbook out of the wrapper.
Now what? How can you make the most of your reading experience?
First, become familiar with the text.
How are chapters arranged?
Are key concepts and phrases highlighted or explained in margins?
Is there a glossary contained within the text?
Is there a review section at the end of each chapter?
Prior to really reading a chapter, just glance through it.
Again, how is it arranged?
What major themes are covered?
You're going to do the same thing when looking at paragraphs.
What is the theme of the paragraph?
Note any unfamiliar terms.
If the text has a glossary, look them up.
No glossary?
Take the time to use a dictionary or the internet.
Pay attention to examples, but know there is a difference between concepts and examples.
Examples are offered to demonstrate concepts.
Try to think of additional examples.
While knowing an example helps to understand the concept,
be certain you understand the concept itself.
If you are having difficulty grasping material or you're simply tired of reading, step away.
Do something else for awhile.
Return later to the text rereading difficult material or picking up where you left off.
Review key themes and concepts, which are usually identified by bolded text,
material set off in margins, or reviewed at the end of the chapter.
Get your monies worth.
Take advantage of any supplemental material made available by the publisher.
Did a CD-ROM accompany the text?
A study guide?
Does the publisher offer a website for the text?
A number of reading strategies exist.
A popular one, SQ3R, has been in use since the 1940s.
Simply SQ3R stands for...survey, question, read, recite, review.
First, as mentioned before, skim the chapter,

not reading...just becoming
familiar with major themes.
Ask questions about the chapter.
What am I looking to learn from the chapter?
What does the chapter indicate it's about?

Begin reading...concentrating
and reflecting on sections.

Don't read the entire chapter and then
try to figure out what is was about.

Recite or recall, aloud or in writing,
key points/phrases from a section.
Do this in your own words.
After you have read the entire chapter, review.
Try to recall the key points/phrases.
Reread any chapters where key points were missed or somewhat fuzzy.
You may want to recite the key points/phrases directly on to note cards for ongoing review
that is portable anywhere, anytime.
Some people find it helpful to take notes while reading.
Note taking, whether during reading or during a lecture, is an often under-appreciated skill.
And, one that takes some practice.
You'll find a method that works for you.
One system, the Cornell Method of Note Taking, has gained some popularity.
Developed by a Cornell University professor, it serves to organize notes
and allows for reflection and review.
Templates are available on the internet to print this note taking paper.
Simply, in the large area you'll want
to write very brief notes noting main ideas of a text or lecture.
On the left-hand area, write questions or important words
that come to mind as you reread the notes.
A second step in the same area, is to answer (or recite) the questions
or discuss why noted words are important.
In the lower section, summarize and reflect on the material.
Review notes from time to time.
Keep in mind that left-hand area becomes a great place to study for an exam.
You have identified important words and have created questions.
